start.speaker: Pixel
start.text: Level 5 - LISTS! Time to organize your data like a pro! ðŸ“‹
start.followUp: Think of lists as your game's inventory system - holding multiple items in one place!

inventoryAnalogy.speaker: Pixel
inventoryAnalogy.text: EXACTLY! Lists are perfect for inventories, high scores, enemy waves, bullet arrays... everything!
inventoryAnalogy.followUp: Any time you need to track multiple things of the same type, lists are your answer!

createList.speaker: Pixel
createList.text: Creating a list is easy - just use square brackets and separate items with commas!
createList.codeExample:
# Empty list
inventory = []

# List with items
weapons = ['sword', 'bow', 'staff']

# Mixed types (Python is flexible!)
player_stats = ['Hero', 100, 15.5, True]

# Numbers list
high_scores = [1000, 850, 720, 650, 500]
createList.followUp: Lists can hold anything - strings, numbers, even other lists!

indexing.speaker: Pixel
indexing.text: Lists use index numbers starting at 0 - like array positions in games!
indexing.codeExample:
inventory = ['potion', 'sword', 'shield', 'map']

# Access items by index
first_item = inventory[0]   # 'potion'
second_item = inventory[1]  # 'sword'
last_item = inventory[-1]   # 'map' (negative counts from end!)

# Check how many items
count = len(inventory)  # 4
indexing.followUp: Remember: First item is [0], not [1]! Classic programmer counting!

options.text: What if I use a wrong index?

indexError.speaker: Pixel
indexError.text: Using an invalid index causes an IndexError - like trying to equip slot 10 when you only have 5 slots!
indexError.codeExample:
items = ['sword', 'shield']

# This works
print(items[0])  # 'sword'

# This crashes!
# print(items[5])  # IndexError!

# Safe way to check:
if len(items) > 5:
    print(items[5])
else:
    print('No item in slot 5!')
indexError.followUp: Always check your list length or use try/except for safety!

options.text: Show me how to add items safely

modifyList.speaker: Pixel
modifyList.text: Lists are mutable - you can change them anytime! Perfect for dynamic game states!
modifyList.codeExample:
inventory = ['sword', 'shield', 'potion']

# Change an item
inventory[0] = 'magic sword'  # Upgrade!

# Swap items
inventory[1], inventory[2] = inventory[2], inventory[1]

print(inventory)  # ['magic sword', 'potion', 'shield']
modifyList.followUp: You can modify lists in-place, unlike strings which are immutable!

options.text: How do I add new items?

addItems.speaker: Pixel
addItems.text: Multiple ways to add items - like picking up loot in a dungeon!
addItems.codeExample:
inventory = ['sword']

# Add one item at the end
inventory.append('potion')

# Add multiple items
inventory.extend(['shield', 'map'])

# Insert at specific position
inventory.insert(1, 'armor')  # Insert at index 1

print(inventory)
# ['sword', 'armor', 'potion', 'shield', 'map']
addItems.followUp: append() for single items, extend() for multiple, insert() for specific positions!

removeItems.speaker: Pixel
removeItems.text: Removing items is like using consumables - they disappear from your inventory!
removeItems.codeExample:
inventory = ['sword', 'potion', 'shield', 'potion', 'map']

# Remove specific item (first occurrence)
inventory.remove('potion')  # Removes first potion

# Remove by index
del inventory[0]  # Removes first item

# Remove and return last item
last_item = inventory.pop()  # Returns 'map'

# Remove and return specific index
item = inventory.pop(1)  # Returns item at index 1

# Clear everything
# inventory.clear()  # Empty list!
removeItems.followUp: remove() by value, pop() to get the item back, del to delete by index!

searchList.speaker: Pixel
searchList.text: Searching lists is crucial for game logic - checking if player has an item!
searchList.codeExample:
inventory = ['sword', 'shield', 'potion', 'map', 'potion']

# Check if item exists
if 'key' in inventory:
    print('You can unlock the door!')
else:
    print('You need a key!')

# Count occurrences
potion_count = inventory.count('potion')  # Returns 2

# Find index of item
if 'map' in inventory:
    map_position = inventory.index('map')  # Returns 3
    print(f'Map is in slot {map_position}')
searchList.followUp: 'in' checks existence, count() counts occurrences, index() finds position!

sortList.speaker: Pixel
sortList.text: Sorting is perfect for leaderboards and organizing inventory!
sortList.codeExample:
# High scores
scores = [500, 1200, 300, 950, 750]
scores.sort()  # Sorts in-place
print(scores)  # [300, 500, 750, 950, 1200]

# Reverse order (highest first)
scores.sort(reverse=True)
print(scores)  # [1200, 950, 750, 500, 300]

# Sort without changing original
original = [5, 2, 8, 1]
sorted_copy = sorted(original)  # Returns new list
print(original)  # Still [5, 2, 8, 1]
print(sorted_copy)  # [1, 2, 5, 8]
sortList.followUp: sort() changes the list, sorted() returns a new sorted list!

slicing.speaker: Pixel
slicing.text: Slicing lets you grab chunks of a list - like selecting multiple items at once!
slicing.codeExample:
items = ['sword', 'shield', 'bow', 'arrow', 'potion', 'map']

# Get first 3 items
first_three = items[0:3]  # ['sword', 'shield', 'bow']
# Or shorter:
first_three = items[:3]   # Same result!

# Get last 2 items
last_two = items[-2:]  # ['potion', 'map']

# Get middle items
middle = items[2:5]  # ['bow', 'arrow', 'potion']

# Copy entire list
copy = items[:]  # Full copy!

# Every other item
every_other = items[::2]  # ['sword', 'bow', 'potion']

nestedLists.speaker: Pixel
nestedLists.text: Lists can contain other lists - perfect for game grids and 2D maps!
nestedLists.codeExample:
# Game board (tic-tac-toe)
board = [
    ['X', 'O', 'X'],
    ['O', 'X', 'O'],
    ['O', 'X', 'X']
]

# Access specific cell
top_left = board[0][0]  # 'X'
middle = board[1][1]    # 'X'

# Inventory with categories
inventory = [
    ['sword', 'dagger', 'bow'],      # Weapons
    ['helmet', 'armor', 'boots'],    # Armor
    ['potion', 'elixir', 'antidote'] # Consumables
]

weapons = inventory[0]
first_weapon = inventory[0][0]  # 'sword'
nestedLists.followUp: Nested lists are the foundation of 2D game worlds!

listTricks.speaker: Pixel
listTricks.text: Here are some pro list techniques for game development!
listTricks.codeExample:
# List comprehension - create lists fast!
enemies_hp = [100 for _ in range(5)]  # [100, 100, 100, 100, 100]

# Filter a list
items = ['sword', 'potion', 'key', 'potion', 'map']
potions = [item for item in items if item == 'potion']

# Transform a list
damages = [10, 20, 15, 25]
doubled = [d * 2 for d in damages]  # [20, 40, 30, 50]

# Zip lists together
names = ['Hero', 'Mage', 'Rogue']
levels = [10, 8, 12]
characters = list(zip(names, levels))
# [('Hero', 10), ('Mage', 8), ('Rogue', 12)]
listTricks.followUp: List comprehensions are Python's superpower for creating lists!

practiceChallenge.speaker: Pixel
practiceChallenge.text: Boss Challenge! Create an inventory management system!
practiceChallenge.followUp: Track items, add loot, use potions, check for keys, and display everything!
practiceChallenge.codeExample:
# Inventory System Challenge
inventory = ['sword', 'potion', 'potion']
max_size = 10

# Add item if space
def add_item(item):
    if len(inventory) < max_size:
        inventory.append(item)
        print(f'Added {item}')
    else:
        print('Inventory full!')

# Use item
def use_item(item):
    if item in inventory:
        inventory.remove(item)
        print(f'Used {item}')
    else:
        print(f'No {item} in inventory!')

# Test it!
add_item('key')
use_item('potion')
print('Current inventory:', inventory)

lessonComplete.speaker: Pixel
lessonComplete.text: ðŸŽŠ LEVEL 5 COMPLETE! You're now a List Master! ðŸ“œ
lessonComplete.followUp: Lists are everywhere in games - inventories, enemies, tiles, scores... You've got the power now!
